questions.question: Which of the following statements is false on the first-degree atrioventricular (AV) block?

options.A: Delayed conduction through the AV node

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) PR interval > 0.50 seconds Explanation: In the first-degree atrioventricular (AV) block , the PR interval is prolonged but typically not greater than 0.50 seconds. A PR interval greater than 0.50 seconds is rare and may suggest a more severe conduction system disease. First-degree atrioventricular (AV) block Definition Delayed conduction through the AV node, (Option A ruled out) resulting in a prolonged PR interval (> 0.20 seconds but < 0.50 seconds) (Option B) Symptoms Rarely symptomatic; often found incidentally on ECG. Causes Physiological (e.g., in athletes with high vagal tone) (Option C) May indicate underlying heart disease. ECG Findings Prolonged (> 0.20 seconds but < 0.50 seconds) but consistent PR interval (Option D) atrioventricular (AV) block" data-author="James Heilman, MD - Own work" data-hash="8788" data-license="CC BY-SA 4.0" data-source="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First-degree_atrioventricular_block#/media/File:FirstAVBlock.jpg" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/LKhGPaW6RCSJUE2H3jBQ1744304072.png" /> Management No treatment required in most cases Reference: Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th edition, Pages 477-478

questions.question: A 65-year-old man with no history of myocardial infarction presents with syncope and is found to have a 2:1 AV block on his ECG. His QRS complex is widened. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism behind his AV block, and how would atropine administration affect his condition? block.

options.A: The block is most likely in the AV node, and atropine will improve AV conduction.
options.B: The block is most likely in the His-Purkinje system, and atropine will improve AV conduction.
options.C: The block is most likely in the AV node, and atropine may increase the degree of AV block.
options.D: The block is most likely in the His-Purkinje system, and atropine may increase the degree of AV

questions.explanation: the degree of AV block. Correct Answer: D) The block is most likely in the His-Purkinje system, and atropine may increase the degree of AV block. Explanation: In cases of 2:1 AV block, a widened QRS complex is more suggestive of a block in the His-Purkinje system rather than the AV node. Atropine typically enhances conduction through the AV node but can worsen AV block in the His-Purkinje system, as it may increase the block by shortening the refractory period of the AV node without improving infranodal conduction. 2:1 Heart block: It is a condition where there is intermittent failure of conduction between the atrium and ventricle, resulting in every other atrial impulse being conducted to the ventricles. This means for every two P waves on an ECG, there is only one QRS complex. Occurs in either the AV node or His-Purkinje system. Cannot be classified as type I or type II second-degree AV block since only one PR interval is observed before the blocked P wave. Progression and Regression Type I or type II second-degree AV block can develop into 2:1 AV block. 2:1 AV block can revert to type I or type II block. Block is in the AV node; atropine improves conduction (Option A): AV nodal block usually has a narrow QRS . Atropine helps nodal blocks, but this case shows wide QRS , suggesting infranodal. Block is in His-Purkinje; atropine improves conduction (Option B): Atropine has minimal or no effect on infranodal (His-Purkinje) blocks. It can even worsen them by increasing sinus rate, making the distal block more evident. Block is in AV node; atropine may worsen it (Option C): Atropine generally improves AV nodal conduction. It doesn’t usually worsen it. Also, the wide QRS makes an AV nodal location less likely .

questions.question: Which among the following are included in the criteria for Metabolic syndrome 1) Waist circumference > 102 cm in men 2) Waist circumference > 88cm in women 3) HDL < 50 mg/dL in men 4) BP >128/88 mm hg 5) Fasting plasma glucose > 100 mg/dL 6) LDL > 200 mg/dL
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C)1,2,5 Explanation: Only Waist circumference (NOT abdomen/hip) > 102 cms (men) & > 88 cms (women) and Fasting plasma glucose > 100 mg/dL among the given options are part of Metabolic syndrome (Syndrome-X) criteria. Metabolic syndrome: Cluster of related conditions like insulin resistance, hypertension, and dyslipidemia predisposes an individual to Cardiovascular conditions and Type-2 diabetes mellitus. Metabolic syndrome/Syndrome-X criteria: 1) Waist circumference > 102 cm in Men > 88 cmin Women 2) HDL levels < 40 mg/dL in Men < 50 mg/dL in Women 3) Triglyceride levels > 150 mg/dL 4) BP (Blood Pressure) > 130/85 mmHg 5) Fasting plasma glucose > 100 mg/dL Clinical presentation/Complications: Nonalcoholic Steatohepatitis (NASH) : Jaundice, Abnormal LFT profile Recurrent Gallstones : Upper quadrant pain Gout (hyperuricemia) : Painful swollen joints Coronary artery disease : Angina Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS): Rotterdam criteria used Obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA): >5 episodes of apnoea for >10s Syndrome-Z: Syndrome-X + Obstructive Sleep Apnoea Treatment: Lifestyle modifications and medical treatment of Hypertension, T2DM and other complications. Reference: Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Pages 3150-3155.

questions.question: All of the following are first-line drugs used in the treatment of chronic heart failure, except
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Furosemide Explanation: Furosemide , though beneficial in acute cases of heart failure, is NOT among the first-line mortality-reducing drugs approved in the treatment of chronic heart failure. First-line drugs used in the treatment of Chronic CHF (mortality-reducing) ARBs/ACE-inhibitors/ARNI Either of these can be started as initial therapy. ACE-inhibitors: Captopril, Enalapril ARBs: Telmisartan, Olmesartan (Option A ruled out) ARNI: ARB+Neprilysin inhibitor - Valsartan-Sacubitril (most preferred 1st line drug) ADR of ACE-i: Cough, angioedema Beta-blockers Cardioselective (2nd gen): Metoprolol, Bisoprolol 3rd gen: Carvedilol (both α - & β - blocking action) - Best beta blocker for heart failure (Option B ruled out) ADR: Bradycardia, Hypotension SGLT-2 Inhibitors Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin ADR: UTI, Forunier gangrene, Euglycemic DKA Aldosterone antagonists Spironolactone (Option C ruled out) ADR: Gynaecomastia Management of CHF with Cardiogenic shock: Vasopressors: Norepinephrine, Dobutamine, Dopamine Inodilators: Milrinone & Amrinone Ca2+ channel sensitizer: Levosimendan Direct myosin activator: Omecamtiv mecarbil Management of Refractory CHF: Left Ventricular Assist Device (LVAD): Heart-mate Cardiac Resynchronization Therapy Cardiac transplant Reference: Davidson’s Principles & Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Pages- 464-468

questions.question: A patient presents with sudden onset breathlessness. On arrival his vitals were, PR- 130 bpm, BP- 180/90 mmHg and spO2- 82% in room air. X-ray done is as shown below. Airway was secured after which his saturation improved. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

options.A: Reassure and monitor vitals of this patient

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Administer IV Furosemide Explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of Acute pulmonary edema . X-ray shows peripheral interstitial opacities. Administration of Loop diuretics like Furosemide is the most appropriate next step after securing airway in a patient with Acute pulmonary edema secondary to Heart failure (CHF). Types of heart failure: HFrEF: Systolic dysfunction, may present acutely. HFpEF: Diastolic dysfunction, usually present as chronic heart failure. Management of CHF: First line drugs used in chronic Heart failure: (mortality-reducing drugs) ARBs/ACE-Inhibitors Beta blockers (2nd gen- cardioselective) SGLT-2 inhibitors (Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin) Anti-aldosterone (Spironolactone) Acute cases with Pulmonary edema: Oxygen: Secure airway and supplement O2 Loop diuretics: IV Furosemide 20-80 mg , reduces preload and systemic venous congestion IV Morphine: if patient is in severe pain/distress, can cause respiratory depression IV Nitroglycerin infusion: reduce afterload Acute decompensated with cardiogenic shock: (low BP) Vasopressors: Norepinephrine, Dobutamine, Dopamine Inodilators: Milrinone & Amrinone Levosimendan: Ca2+ channel sensitizer Omecamtiv mecarbil: Direct myosin activator Non-pharmacological treatment: Implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICD) Coronary revascularisation: in Coronary artery disease patients Ventricular assist devices Cardiac transplantation Reassure and monitor vitals of this patient (Option A):

questions.question: A patient, known case of Coronary artery disease presented with fatigue. Echocardiography done showed reduced ejection fraction. What could be the most likely electrolyte disturbance seen in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Hyponatremia and Hypokalemia Explanation: The patient has Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) ; the most likely electrolyte abnormalities are, Hypokalemia: due to Hyperaldosteronism caused by RAAS activation Hyponatremia: due to water retention causing dilutional hyponatremia Workup in CHF: Serum Elevated BNP/N-terminal pro-BNP levels (BNP- Brain Natriuretic Peptide) Hyponatremia (Water retention - dilutional hypoNa+) Hypokalemia (RAAS activation) Hyperaldosteronism Renal function tests: Urea, Creatinine (Renal failure can occur as a complication) Radiological findings Earliest: Prominent upper lobe pulmonary veins (Antral sign/ Reverse-Mustache sign) Batwing-shaped opacities - pulmonary edema Costophrenic angle blunting Kerley B lines: Horizontal lines in costophrenic angle perpendicular to the pleural surface. Echocardio- graphy Reduced ejection fraction: seen in systolic dysfunction (HFrEF) Normal to mildly reduced EF: seen in diastolic dysfunction (HFpEF) Cardiac MRI Preferred imaging modality to differentiate systolic and diastolic dysfunction. Used for prognosis. BORG scale: used for functional assessment of CHF patients Reference: Davidson’s Principles & Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 464 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8977263/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3387448/

questions.question: A 50 year old male gives a history of fatigue and dyspnoea upon lying down for 1 week. On examination, his vitals were: HR-130 bpm, BP-150/90 mmHg, S3+ on auscultation. Chest X-ray is as shown in the image below. Which among the following in this patient is not part of the major criterion according to Framingham’s?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) HR-130 bpm Explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of Congestive Heart Failure (CHF), and the X-ray shows Cardiomegaly. Tachycardia (HR>120 bpm) is a part of Minor criterion in Framingham’s Diagnostic criteria (not Major). Other clinical features- Dyspnoea upon lying down (Orthopnoea) , S3 (Gallop rhythm) and Cardiomegaly (X-ray) are part of Major criteria. Framingham diagnostic criteria for Heart Failure: Major criteria Minor criteria Acute pulmonary edema (crepitations/rales) Cardiomegaly (Option B) PND/Orthopnoea (Option A) Elevated JVP, Abdominojugular reflex S3 gallop rhythm + (Option D) Ankle edema (pitting pedal edema) Dyspnoea on exertion Tender hepatomegaly Nocturnal cough Pleural effusion Tachycardia (HR>120 bpm) (Option C) Stages of CHF: Stage A Only risk factors - Hypertension, DM, Atherosclerosis, Obesity, etc. present NO structural damage Stage B Structural heart disease is present (e.g., LVH, dysmotility on ECHO, etc.) NO signs/symptoms seen Stage C Most common clinical stage Signs/symptoms seen pertaining to CHF Stage D No response to any medical therapy - known as Refractory heart failure Only treatment is Cardiac transplant

questions.question: A 68-year-old male is presenting with sudden loss of consciousness and collapse. He had pallor during the attack. ECG is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Third-degree atrioventricular block Explanation: The ECG shows complete AV dissociation, which is indicative of third-degree atrioventricular block. Third-degree atrioventricular block Definition Complete failure of conduction between atria and ventricles, resulting in independent beating (AV dissociation). Ventricular Activity Maintained by an escape rhythm from: - The AV node or bundle of His (narrow QRS complexes). - Distal Purkinje tissues (broad QRS complexes). Clinical Features - Recurrent syncope or 'Stokes–Adams' attacks- sudden loss of consciousness and collapse. - Brief anoxic seizure. - Pallor and a death-like appearance during the attack; characteristic flush upon recovery. - Rapid recovery distinguishes it from epilepsy. Management - Depends on clinical circumstances. - Transient AV block in acute inferior myocardial infarction- no treatment if the patient remains stable. - Symptomatic third-degree AV block- intravenous atropine or intravenous isoprenaline to maintain circulation until temporary pacing is inserted. - Permanent pacemaker. Myocardial infarction (Option B): MI can cause AV block, but MI itself doesn't present with AV dissociation as the primary ECG finding. More likely to show ST changes , not isolated AV dissociation. Mobitz I (Wenckebach) (Option C): Progressive PR prolongation before a dropped beat. Usually asymptomatic or mild symptoms. Not associated with complete AV dissociation. Mobitz II block (Option D): Sudden dropped QRS without PR prolongation. May cause syncope, but still has some P-QRS association , unlike complete AV block . Can progress to third-degree block, but not AV dissociation by definition . Reference: Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th edition, Pages 477-478

questions.question: Identify the type of heart block from the ECG given below.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Mobitz type I block Explanation: Given ECG shows progressive lengthening of PR intervals until a dropped beat occurs, which indicates Mobitz type I block Second-degree heart block Dropped beats occur because some impulses from the atria fail to be transmitted to the ventricles. Types Mobitz Type I ( Wenckebach ) (Option B) Mobitz Type II (Option C) Description Progressive lengthening of PR intervals until a dropped beat occurs. Cycle repeats itself. PR interval remains constant. Some P waves are not conducted. Clinical Features Often physiological; can occur in young athletes. May not cause symptoms. Caused by His–Purkinje system disease. Higher risk of asystole. Management Typically does not require treatment. Monitor for changes; consider underlying heart disease. May require treatment if symptomatic. Consider temporary pacing. Monitor closely due to the risk of progression. First-degree AV block (Option A ) - the PR interval is prolonged but typically not greater than 0.50 seconds, i.e. > 0.20 seconds but < 0.50 seconds. ECG does not show any dropped beat. Third-degree AV block (Option D) - ECG shows complete AV dissociation due to complete failure of conduction between atria and ventricles Reference: Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th edition, Pages 477-478

questions.question: A 68-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with palpitations and shortness of breath. The ECG is given below and has an irregular rhythm with at least three distinct P-wave morphologies. The heart rate is 120 beats per minute. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia Explanation: Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia is characterized by at least three distinct P-wave morphologies, an atrial rate between 100 and 150 bpm , and irregular rhythm. It is often associated with chronic pulmonary diseases like COPD. Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) ECG Characteristics At least three distinct P-wave morphologies Atrial rates typically between 100-150 bpm . Clear isoelectric intervals between P waves (unlike atrial fibrillation) Atrial rate slower than atrial fibrillation Mechanism Caused by automaticity from multiple atrial foci, with multiple areas in the atria spontaneously generating electrical impulses. Common Causes Chronic pulmonary disease Acute illness Atrial Fibrillation (Option A): Characterized by absent P waves and an irregularly irregular rhythm without distinct P-wave morphologies. Atrial Flutter (Option C): Typically shows a "sawtooth" pattern on ECG, with regular atrial activity and rapid atrial rates, distinct from the multiple P-wave morphologies seen in MAT. Sinus Tachycardia (Option D): Shows a regular rhythm with normal P waves , not the distinct and multiple P-wave morphologies seen in MAT.

questions.question: Which of the following statements on transvenous pacing is wrong?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Permanent method of pacing Explanation: Transvenous pacing is a longer-term temporary pacing method. Aspect Transcutaneous Pacing Transvenous Pacing Purpose Temporary, fast initiation for symptomatic bradyarrhythmias or cardiac arrest. Longer-term temporary pacing for evaluation of permanent pacemaker need. (Option C) Initiation Time Fastest method, used in emergencies (e.g., bradycardia, asystole). Requires more time due to the need for central venous access. (Option A and Option D) Electrode Placement Anterior pad: cardiac apex or lead V3 position. Posterior pad: inferior to scapula or between scapula and spine. Intracardiac lead placement through a central vein (e.g., femoral, subclavian). (Option B ruled out)

questions.question: A 72-year-old male presents with dizziness. His heart rate is 38 bpm, blood pressure 80/50 mmHg, and ECG confirms sinus bradycardia. What is the medication to be used?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) IV atropine 0.5 mg every 3-5 minutes Explanation: In this scenario, the patient has hemodynamically unstable bradycardia and the treatment is IV atropine 0.5 mg every 3-5 minutes. Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that blocks the muscarinic receptors in the SA node thus preventing the binding of acetylcholine released from the Vagus nerve , thus allowing the increase in heart rate Other uses of atropine: Used as preanesthetic agent Organophosphate poisoning Ophthalmologic examinations Side effects of atropine Dry Mouth and Thirst : due to reduced saliva production Blurred Vision : Pupil dilation and loss of accommodation Urinary Retention : Atropine can affect the bladder muscles, making it difficult to urinate Constipation : Reduced gut motility Increased Heart Rate (Tachycardia) Confusion and Hallucinations Flushing and Overheating Sinus bradycardia Definition Sinus bradycardia is a cardiac rhythm with normal sinus node depolarization but a rate < 60 bpm. Diagnostic Criteria ECG showing sinus rhythm at a rate lower than 60 bpm. Common Etiologies Normal in athletes Medications (beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, digoxin) Hypothyroidism, hypothermia Sick sinus syndrome, myocardial infarction Vagal stimulation (e.g., vasovagal syncope) Clinical Features Asymptomatic (in many patients) Fatigue Dizziness or lightheadedness Exercise intolerance Syncope or presyncope Cognitive slowing Worsening angina or heart failure symptoms Evaluation Assess hemodynamic stability ECG to confirm sinus rhythm Review medication list for bradycardic agents Evaluate for comorbidities (e.g., hypothyroidism, myocardial infarction) Management If Hemodynamically Unstable: IV atropine 0.5 mg every 3-5 minutes (max 3 mg) (Option A) If there is no improvement, consider a temporary pacemaker If Stable: Treat underlying causes Withdraw bradycardia-inducing medications Evaluate for permanent pacemaker Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK493201/

questions.question: A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease presents to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath over the past 3 days. His blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg, and he has bilateral pitting edema in his lower extremities. Lung auscultation reveals crackles at the bases. His chest X-ray shows cardiomegaly and pulmonary congestion. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism contributing to his symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Left ventricular systolic dysfunction Explanation: The most common cause of congestive heart failure is left ventricular systolic dysfunction, where the heart’s ability to pump blood is diminished, leading to fluid backup into the lungs and symptoms such as dyspnea, orthopnea, and pulmonary congestion. Congestive Heart Failure - Clinical Features Cardiac output decreased Stroke volume decreased Heart rate increased Increased sympathetic drive leading to palpitations and diaphoresis Orthopnea Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea Clinical Features of Left-Sided vs. Right-Sided Congestive Heart Failure (CHF) Left-Sided Heart Failure Right-Sided Heart Failure Causes : Ischemic heart disease (myocardial infarction). Hypertension Dilated cardiomyopathy. Aortic or mitral valve disease. Causes : Left-sided heart failure ( most common cause ). Chronic lung diseases (COPD, pulmonary hypertension). Pulmonary embolism. Right ventricular infarction. In left-sided heart failure, the left ventricle cannot effectively pump blood to the body, leading to a backup of blood into the lungs. Clinical features: This primarily results in pulmonary symptoms. Dyspnea Exertional dyspnea). Orthopnea Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea Pulmonary Congestion: Crackles (rales) heard on auscultation due to fluid in the alveoli. Cough Wheezing (cardiac asthma). Fatigue and Weakness Decreased Exercise Tolerance Limited physical activity due to breathlessness and fatigue. S3 Gallop Cool Extremities: Reduced cardiac output may cause poor peripheral circulation, leading to cold, pale skin. In right-sided heart failure, the right ventricle fails to pump blood effectively into the pulmonary circulation, leading to systemic venous congestion. It is often secondary to left-sided heart failure or conditions affecting the lungs (cor pulmonale). Clinical Features: Peripheral Edema Jugular Venous Distension (JVD) Hepatomegaly B/L pitting pedal edema Kussmaul sign: JVP elevation on inspiration Ascites Nocturia Weight Gain Anorexia and Nausea Increased cardiac output (Option A): This is not typical of heart failure, where cardiac output is usually reduced. Increased cardiac output is more characteristic of hyperdynamic states like hyperthyroidism or anemia. Decreased preload (Option B): Preload is often increased in heart failure due to fluid retention, not decreased. Decreasing preload is often a therapeutic target to relieve symptoms of heart failure (through diuretics). Pulmonary embolism (Option D): While a pulmonary embolism can cause acute dyspnea, it is not the underlying mechanism in this case, as the patient’s symptoms, crackles on lung auscultation, and signs of fluid overload are more suggestive of heart failure. Reference: www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430873/

questions.question: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and dizziness over the past week. He denies any chest pain or syncope. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB) Explanation: Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB): The ECG findings of an rsR' pattern (rabbit ears) in lead V1, a wide QRS (>120 ms), and a broad S wave in leads I and V6 are classic for RBBB. Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB) Description Right bundle branch block (RBBB) is an electrocardiogram finding that occurs when the physiologic electrical conduction system of the heart, specifically in the His-Purkinje system, is altered or interrupted resulting in a widened QRS and electrocardiographic vector changes Etiopathogenesis Structural Heart Disease: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) Heart Failure Valvular Heart Disease: Aortic stenosis or regurgitation, mitral stenosis, or regurgitation, leading to right heart strain and RBBB. Cardiomyopathies : Dilated or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Pulmonary Causes: Pulmonary Embolism (PE) : Large emboli can cause acute right heart strain, leading to RBBB. Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) Pulmonary Hypertension Infiltrative Diseases: Amyloidosis Sarcoidosis Due to the anatomy of the right bundle branch, damage typically occurs at 3 different locations. The proximal right bundle nearest the endocardium is the most common location to be affected. The distal right bundle is typically only injured when the moderator band is transected during surgery. The terminal right bundle is injured during ventriculotomy or transatrial resectio Clinical features Often asymptomatic and found incidentally. In some cases, patients may experience palpitations, dizziness, or lightheadedness. When associated with other cardiac pathology (heart failure, ischemia), it may indicate an underlying issue. Wide split S2 heart sound heard. Diagnosis The characteristic ECG findings for right bundle branch block are as follows: QRS duration is greater than or equal to 120 milliseconds. In lead V1 and V2, there is an RSR` in leads V1 and V2. In Leads 1 and V6, the S wave is of greater duration than the R wave, or the S wave is greater than 40 milliseconds. questions.question: A 70-year-old male with a history of chronic hypertension and known Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) presents to the emergency department with acute chest pain radiating to the left arm. His ECG shows a wide QRS complex due to LBBB. You are concerned about a possible myocardial infarction (MI), and consider using the Sgarbossa criteria. Which of the following findings would be consistent with a positive Sgarbossa criterion for acute myocardial infarction? ≥ 1 mm in leads with a positive QRS complex ≥ 1 mm in leads with a negative QRS complex ≥ 1 mm in any anterior lead (V1-V3) ≥ 1 mm in any lead
questions.explanation: ≥ 1 mm in leads with a positive QRS complex Correct Answer: A) Concordant ST elevation ≥ 1 mm in leads with a positive QRS complex infarction (MI) is challenging due to abnormal depolarization and repolarization patterns. The Sgarbossa criteria help identify MI in this setting. The most specific criterion is concordant ST elevation ≥ 1 mm in leads where the QRS complex is also positive (i.e., the ST segment and QRS complex are in the same direction), making Option A correct. This finding strongly suggests transmural injury and is less likely to occur from LBBB alone. Sgarbossa criteria Used to diagnose acute myocardial infarction (AMI) in the presence of a Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) or ventricular-paced rhythm, where typical ECG changes of MI may be obscured by the abnormal conduction pattern. Criteria 1. Concordant ST elevation ≥ 1 mm in any lead with a positive QRS complex (QRS and ST segment in the same direction). Score: 5 points This finding is highly specific for acute MI. 2. Concordant ST depression ≥ 1 mm in leads V1, V2, or V3 (with a negative QRS complex). Score: 3 points ST depression in these leads suggests posterior infarction. 3. Discordant ST elevation (ST elevation ≥ 5 mm) in leads with a negative QRS complex (QRS and ST segment in opposite directions). Score: 2 points Modified Sgarbossa Criteria A modification to the original criteria uses a ST/S ratio in discordant leads. ST elevation must be ≥ 25% of the depth of the preceding S wave in leads with a negative QRS complex (instead of ≥ 5 mm). Interpretation A total score of ≥ 3 points is considered suggestive of acute MI in the setting of LBBB. Discordant ST elevation ≥ 1 mm in leads with a negative QRS complex (Option B) : Discordant ST elevation must be ≥ 5 mm to meet the Sgarbossa criteria. Concordant ST elevation ≥ 1 mm in any anterior lead (V1-V3) (Option C) is n ot part of the Sgarbossa criteria either. Concordant ST depression (not elevation) in leads V1 to V3 is used as part of the Sgarbossa criteria to suggest possible posterior MI. Discordant ST depression ≥ 1 mm in any lead (Option D) is not a part of the Sgarbossa criteria. Discordant ST elevation ≥ 5 mm is a criterion, but depression is not.

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of occasional chest discomfort and shortness of breath on exertion.His medical history includes hypertension and diabetes. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D. Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) Explanation: LBBB is characterized by a widened QRS complex (>120 ms), a broad and notched R wave in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6 (lateral leads), and a deep S wave in V1 and V2. The lack of Q waves in the lateral leads is also typical. Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) Description Left bundle branch block (LBBB) is an intraventricular conduction abnormality usually caused by ischemic or mechanical factors affecting the cardiac conduction system's left bundle branch. Etiology Structural heart disease: Coronary artery disease (CAD), hypertension, cardiomyopathies such as dilated, left ventricular noncompaction, stress, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathies, and aortic valve diseases like aortic stenosis and regurgitation Degenerative changes: Age-related fibrosis, Lev disease, and Lenègre disease Infiltrative conditions: sarcoidosis or amyloidosis Inflammatory cardiomyopathies: Infectious myocarditis or autoimmune disease Hyperkalemia Antiarrhythmic medications Pathogenesis Electrical Dyssynchrony: With LBBB, the right ventricle is activated first, followed by a right-to-left septal transmission and activation of the left ventricular endocardium at the level of the mid septum. Mechanical Dyssynchrony: In LBBB, the septum is activated before aortic valve opening (isovolumetric contraction), stretching the posterior and lateral walls Clinical features LBBB may be silent, especially in its early stages, or present with nonspecific symptoms, such as fatigue, dyspnea, and palpitations. Symptoms due to underlying heart disease can include chest pain, dyspnea, fatigue, palpitations, syncope, or presyncope. Diagnosis ECG findings QRS duration greater than or equal to 120 ms. Broad notched or slurred R wave in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6 or, occasionally, an RS pattern in leads V5 and V6. Absence of Q wave in leads I, V5, and V6 (with the possible exception of aVL). R wave peak time greater than 60 ms in leads V5 and V6. ST-T waves change opposite to the QRS direction. Echocardiography Stress Imaging Electrophysiological studies Differential Diagnosis Incomplete Left Bundle Branch Block Ventricular Paced

questions.question: What is the heart rate if there are 5 large boxes between R waves on an ECG?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 60 beats per minute Explanation: Heart Rate = 300/Number of Large Boxes between R-R interval or 1500/ Number of small boxes between R-R interval Heart rate = 300/5= 60 beats per minute Normal ECG: ECG recordings are typically made on graph paper, where time is represented horizontally and voltage vertically. ECG is a non-invasive diagnostic modality that has a substantial clinical impact on investigating the severity of cardiovascular diseases. ECG is increasingly being used for monitoring patients on antiarrhythmics and other drugs, as an integral part of preoperative assessment of patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery, and for screening individuals in high-risk occupations. Small box (1 mm): Each small box represents 0.04 seconds (40 milliseconds). Large box (5 mm): A large box consists of 5 small boxes and represents 0.20 seconds (200 milliseconds). Cardiac Axis: Refers to the direction of the heart's depolarization wavefront in the frontal plane. A typical cardiac axis is between -30 to +90 degrees. A left axis deviation (between 0 and -90 degrees) is defined by the presence of positive QRS in the lead I and negative in lead aVF. Right axis deviation (+90 and 180 degrees) is determined by the presence of negative QRS in lead I and positive in lead aVF. P wave It represents atrial depolarization on the ECG. As atrial depolarization is initiated by the SA node located in the right atrium, the right atrium gets depolarized first, followed by left atrial depolarization. Its duration is three small squares wide and 2.5 small squares high. PR Interval It represents the time from the beginning of atrial depolarization to the start of ventricular depolarization and includes the delay at the AV node. The average interval is 3 to 5 small squares (120 to 200 ms). QRS complex It represents ventricular depolarization as current passes down the AV node. A standard QRS complex has a duration of less than three small squares (under 120 ms, usually 60 to 100 ms). Septal Q-Wave Represents the depolarization of the interventricular septum. Its amplitude is not bigger than 0.1 mV, R-Wave It is the tallest wave of the QRS complex, representing the electrical stimulus as it passes down the ventricles during depolarization. S-Wave It represents the final depolarization of the Purkinje fibers. It is any downward deflection after R-wave. T-Wave It represents ventricular repolarization. The suggested criteria for the typical T wave include the size of one-eighth or less than two-thirds of the size of the R wave and a height of less than 10 mm. ST-Segment It depicts the end of ventricular depolarization and the beginning of ventricular repolarization. The average duration of the ST segment is less than 2 to 3 small squares (80-120 ms). QT-Interval It represents the start of depolarization to the end of the repolarization of ventricles. Generally, the normal QT interval is less than 400 to 440 milliseconds (ms), or 0.4 to 0.44 seconds. U-Wave Small wave that follows the T wave. It represents the delayed repolarization of the papillary muscles or Purkinje fibers. It is commonly associated with hypokalemia.

questions.question: A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the ER with palpitations and shortness of breath. His ECG shows an irregular rhythm with at least three distinct P-wave morphologies and a heart rate of 120 beats per minute. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management approach for this patient?

options.C: Correcting underlying metabolic abnormalities and treating the underlying lung disease

questions.explanation: disease Correct Answer: C) Correcting underlying metabolic abnormalities and treating the underlying lung disease Explanation : Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is a heart rhythm disorder that is often triggered by acute illnesses and metabolic abnormalities, especially in patients with chronic pulmonary disease. By addressing these issues, correcting underlying metabolic abnormalities and treating the underlying lung disease the arrhythmia may resolve without the need for antiarrhythmic drugs. Multifocal atrial tachycardia ECG Characteristics At least three distinct P-wave morphologies Atrial rates typically between 100-150 bpm. Clear isoelectric intervals between P waves (unlike atrial fibrillation) Atrial rate slower than atrial fibrillation Mechanism Caused by automaticity from multiple atrial foci, with multiple areas in the atria spontaneously generating electrical impulses. Common Causes Chronic pulmonary disease Acute illness Treatment Approaches Treat underlying disease : Most important step. Correct metabolic abnormalities : Address electrolyte imbalances. Calcium channel blockers : Verapamil or diltiazem to slow atrial and ventricular rate. Amiodarone : Can be effective but avoided long-term due to potential toxicities (e.g., pulmonary fibrosis). (Option D ruled out) Thromboembolism Risk Not as well-defined or high as in atrial fibrillation or flutter. Electrical cardioversion (Option A) : Electrical cardioversion is generally ineffective in the management of MAT. This is because the arrhythmia originates from multiple atrial foci rather than a single reentrant circuit, which is more responsive to cardioversion. Intravenous beta-blockers (Option B): While beta-blockers can be effective in slowing the heart rate, they are often not well-tolerated in patients with severe pulmonary disease like COPD. Beta-blockers can exacerbate bronchospasm , making this option inappropriate in such cases.
